title: The Joys of Orienteering
instructions: You are going to read an article about the sport of orienteering. For questions 22–35, choose from the people (A–D). The people may be chosen more than once.

texts.content: Anna Peirce, ten years old and out of breath, is lost. Admittedly, her mother is standing only a metre away, but Anna has to find her on her own and master the skills she must use. The Peirces took up orienteering three years ago at the suggestion of a friend. Now the family attends events each weekend, anything up to 150 kilometres away. 'It’s such fun,' says Anna. ‘And the best thing is trying not to get bored when playing with other kids my age. Now I want to be as good as the top competitors.’

evidence.text: The Peirces took up orienteering three years ago at the suggestion of a friend
I want to be as good as the top competitors

texts.content: ‘It is as much a competition against the course, yourself and your judgment, as it is against other people,’ says Jerry Newcombe, vice-chairman of Southampton Orienteering Club and organiser of the meeting this morning. ‘The great thing is that people of every age can enjoy it. A plodder can get just as much fun as someone who covers the course within minutes. A couple of kilometres with poor path visibility is quite difficult to negotiate. It is more demanding than walking but still pleasant. And bad conditions are part of the fun,’ he says. ‘This sport is growing fast, attracting more and more families.’

evidence.text: people of every age can enjoy it
bad conditions are part of the fun

texts.content: A year ago, Julia Wigley had no intention of competing. ‘I’d never even heard of it,’ she says. She began taking her 11-year-old daughter to local events. ‘But I got bored standing watching, so I had a go myself,’ she says. ‘You’re always getting wet and muddy as you race with the youngsters. It takes more skill than going for a run.’ Julia says she likes the fact that competitors of all ages work together, and she enjoys the social side as she runs under the finishing tape.

evidence.text: competitors of all ages work together

texts.content: Ian Diamond, a tall, strong-looking professor at Southampton University, talks about the sport in which a competitor has to read a map, interpret terrain and beat a 12-minute kilometre. ‘Feeling cold, wet or tired is all part of the fun, and this is a great way to stay fit,’ he says. He runs with the club regularly and enjoys the company of others. ‘The scenery is beautiful and I’d rather be doing nothing else on a Sunday,’ he adds.

evidence.text: I'd rather be doing nothing else on a Sunday
